What worked:
- Explaining the purpose of concepts: assert, helper functions, dictionaries to store intermediate computations instead of just suggesting edits.
- Providing a well-written summary of feedback, not just a number.
- Showing students how to tie course concepts like inheritance to clean up project code, because students don't have exposure to that perspective.
- Providing references to students like PEP-8.

What didn't work:
- Nitpicking every detail in a submission, especially style guide rule violations. Students tended to focus on these smallest, concrete mistakes (e.g. spaces between operators) instead of more important conceptual misunderstandings (e.g. when to use recursion). Also poor for confidence.
- Falling behind because of perfectionism, which decreased work motivation. Introductory course for CS majors covering functional, object-oriented, and declarative programming; basic recursive data structures; interpreting programs just as other data. Taught in Python.

Accomplishments: 
- Guided a group of 30 students through labs and discussion.
- Contributed to office hours queue web application.
- SQL aggregation lab focusing on linguistic data as an application.

What worked: 
- Deconstructing the process for drawing simple environment diagrams. Make sure students have mastered every single step. This can take several iterations of examples, exercise, and sharing.
- 1-on-1 appointments with students.
- Physical demonstrations. Had students count the number of people in the room using tree recursion.
- Big picture. Share experiences, applications to other domains.
- Focus on teaching problem solving, not go through the work packets.
- Examples. Concepts are the end, not the means to the end.
 
What didn't work:
- Teaching while overburdened. Sleep is important.
- Saying "___ is easy" to reassure students that they can do it. It had the opposite effect.
- Going through queue too fast in crowded office hours. Only identified bugs and then asked students to "think about it". Got students unstuck, but did not do as much for understanding.
- Explaining using rules/abstract concepts. Examples and worked better.
- Giving students too little to work with. Examples were more engaging, not just hints directly related to the solution.
- Focusing on perfection. Recognize you're not perfect either. Focus on variety of approaches and creativity.

- Explaining the purpose of concepts: assert, helper functions, dictionaries to store intermediate computations instead of just suggesting edits.

- Showing students how to tie course concepts like inheritance to clean up project code, because students don't have exposure to that perspective.
- Providing references to students like PEP-8.

What didn't work:
- Nitpicking every detail in a submission, especially style guide rule violations. Students tended to focus on these smallest, concrete mistakes (e.g. spaces between operators) instead of more important conceptual misunderstandings (e.g. when to use recursion). Also poor for confidence.
